body: These were super opaque wrappers of the host command line  now bin powershell  that passed command line arguments of where to find things.  With the recent refactor of the build system and the host itself, all of these scripts were rendered totally unnecessary. A few environment variables still need to be set  read  key value pairs    env LD_LIBRARY_PATH=lib CORE_ROOT=src monad ext coreclr Runtime PWRSH_ROOT=lib PSMODULEPATH=lib Modules bin powershell lib powershell run.exe  It is much simpler now to understand how PowerShell itself is launched, from start to finish. Shell in a box Docker file might come back.  VSO create date - 10/27/2015 9:39:00     VSO closed date - 10/27/2015 9:40:00

body: Add top level Makefile   Recursively call make in monad native  powershell native bits    Add monad build submodule  powershell managed bits    Recursively call make in monad build   Move Windows build mapping scripts to monad build   Refactor monad build makefile      PowerShell managed bits only     clean up dependencies     revert to `make all; make test` idiom     build only xUnit tests  not Pester      rename ps_test.dll to PowerShell.Linux.Tests     add correct clean and distclean targets     build TypeCatalogGen.exe and artifacts locally     output PowerShell libraries to monad linux lib     reduce dependencies to just PowerShell requried files  i.e. no copying of CoreCLR etc.      include custom assembly load path Makefile     include powershell run Makefile   bring back `make prepare` as one time `make bootstrap`   add proper clean, clean subproject, distclean, and distclean subproject targets   make all delegates to powershell native and powershell managed bits   $ MONAD  and $ PSLIB  are exported   make test in monad linux runs Pester tests   toplevel Makefile is now only  100 LOC  VSO create date - 10/27/2015 9:28:00     VSO closed date - 10/27/2015 9:38:00

body: Rather than it being given an assembly to launch, I want it to automatically launch the appropriate assembly if given no arguments inline script file script, and ensure it works for hashbang as well. This would then deprecate all the runps scripts.  It would get us well on the way to packaging, as we'll have a simple `powershell` executable that acts like people would expect.  We should also look in smarter places for the environment variables, and move the PowerShell libraries to lib powershell, and coreclr libraries to lib coreclr ? .  The monad linux Makefile should then take a DESTDIR  or prefix  to place lib and bin correctly  note that CMake in monad native should be passed a flag instead of resolving up itself . body: The current pswin job is super tightly coupled and side effect dependent on several scripts. It's also super slow. I intend to refactor it into 'razzlespy' and 'makegen' jobs. The razzlespy job has one big issue  it must be run from its folder, and will output to there as well. The makegen job needs to be refactored. The current way it takes the list of DLLs we use violates DRY badly. Once this is fixed, it just needs to be setup as a downstream job and should work pretty well. VSO create date - 10/6/2015 18:25:00     VSO closed date - 10/29/2015 20:44:00
title: Cleanup Windows build mapping job(s)

body: It looked like a Makefile and quacked like a Makefile, but it was not a Makefile. Instead, I had to take the rules I'd written and evaluate them in our Makefile, and simply write the output to a hardcoded  but now automatically generated  powershell.inc; effectively mocking its generation on Windows without depending on their build system. NOW it works. VSO create date - 10/6/2015 15:43:00     VSO closed date - 10/6/2015 15:44:00

body: Add tests to ensure expected behavior of arithmetic operations.      binary operator tests     very large number tests     very small number tests     zero tests     order of operations     equality tests     used with the  math  static .Net class     arithmetic with casting   e.g.,  int $var1 = 2.2 dereferences 2.  Ensure arithmetic carries through  ;  int ,  double , fails on  string      division by zero   \*  1.1 1.04 = 0.0600000000000001  a result of implementing ieee 754    We are assuming that arithmetic in PSL works, since it's based on C#, which we are assuming works. https   en.wikipedia.org wiki IEEE_floating_point#Recommended_operations   Recommended arithmetic operations, which must round correctly  12   ex, 2x, 10x  ex ? 1, 2x ? 1, 10x ? 1  loge x , log2 x , log10 x   loge 1   x , log2 1   x , log10 1   x   ûx2   y2  1 ûx   1   x n  x1 n  xn, xy  sin x , cos x , tan x   asin x , acos x , atan x , atan2 y,x   sinPi x  = sin ãx , cosPi x  = cos ãx , atanPi x  = atan x  ã, atan2Pi y,x   sinh x , cosh x , tanh x   asinh x , acosh x , atanh x   The asinPi, acosPi and tanPi functions are not part of the standard because the feeling was that they were less necessary. 13  The first two are mentioned in a paragraph, but this is regarded as an error. 14   http   ieeexplore.ieee.org stamp stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=4610935  page 42   VSO create date - 9/30/2015 17:30:00

body: We can reproduce this now. xUnit, Pester, etc. can't right to stdout if it's not running as root.  The problem actually stems from trying to write directly to  dev stdout when running as another user via sudo  both what the container now does and what I was doing to repro it on the Jenkins slave . CoreFX already contains what I believe to be a fix  https   github.com dotnet corefx pull 3352  Once we've updated CoreCLR, we can backport this fix by bringing in the latest System.Console.dll, and test if it resolves our issue. Otherwise we'll need to find a work around.  Simple repro steps   sudo  u someuser bash echo hi >  dev stdout  Should get a permissions error.  This is  fixed  by pulling in an update to System.Console, which is blocked until CoreCLR is updated.  Patch backported to old version of CLR.  VSO create date - 9/25/2015 9:36:00     VSO closed date - 10/1/2015 14:02:00
